document.masterDocTitle: Revision and phylogenetic assessment of the rove beetle genus Pseudohesperus Hayashi, with broad reference to the subtribe Philonthina (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Staphylinini)

caption.paragraph:
Figure 22. Variation of the apical portion of male sternite IX and paramere of aedeagus in species of the genus
Pseudohesperus
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description: Head and pronotum black, shining. Antennae black-brown. Elytra and scutellum black. Abdomen black with strongly iridescent lustre. Mandibles, maxillary and labial palpi reddish-brown. Legs reddish-brown or dark brown.

Body 8.73â€“10.5 mm long (HPL: 2.77â€“2.94 mm ). Head of rounded quadrangular shape, 1.06â€“1.14 mm long, 1.22â€“1.31 mm wide, slightly wider than long (HW: HL = 1.07â€“1.23). Tempora 0.25â€“0.33 mm long, almost evenly rounded, densely and coarsely punctate; eyes moderately large, slightly prominent, 0.41â€“ 0.49 mm long, 1.25â€“1.66 times as long as tempora. Dorsal surface of head with moderately numerous, large setiferous punctures, becoming sparser toward vertex; vertex largely impunctate. Entire head with distinct and dense microsculpture of transverse waves. Antennae long, antennomere I very long, distinctly thickened towards apex, antennomere III much longer than antennomere II, following antennomeres gradually decreasing in length, but all distinctly longer than wide, antennomere XI obliquely truncated.

Pronotum slightly narrowed anteriad, 1.55â€“ 1.71 mm long, 1.55â€“1.71 mm wide, slightly wider than head (PW: HW = 1.19â€“1.33), densely and finely punctate, punctures separated by three to five times their diameter, narrowly impunctate along midline; microsculpture fine, similar to that on head.

subSubSection.paragraph: Elytra 1.80â€“1.96 mm long, 2.12â€“2.28 mm wide, along sides about 1.16â€“1.21 times as long as pronotum, densely and finely punctate, punctures separated about one puncture diameter. Scutellum large, triangular, densely and finely punctuate.

Abdomen a little narrowed posteriad, widest 1.88â€“ 2.04 mm , finely and densely punctate, punctures separated by two to three times their diameter at base on tergites IIIâ€“V and punctures separated by less than one puncture diameter at base on tergites VIâ€“VII, punctation gradually becoming sparser toward apex of each tergite; tergites IIIâ€“V with two basal carinae, elevated area between basal carinae densely and coarsely punctate.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 25.
Pseudohesperus luteus
sp. nov.
A, aedeagus, dorsal (parameral side) view; B, median lobe of aedeagus, lateral view; C, D, underside of paramere; E, sternite IX of male; F, sternite VIII of male; G, tergite X of female; H, tergite X of male; I, gonocoxites of genital segment of female. Scale bars = 0.5 mm.

Figure 24.
Pseudohesperus eustilbus (Kraatz)
. A, aedeagus, dorsal (parameral side) view; B, median lobe of aedeagus, lateral view; C, D, underside of paramere; E, sternite IX of male; F, tergite VIII of male; G, sternite VIII of male; H, stylus of tergite IX of male; I, sternite VIII of female; J, tergite X of female; K, tergite X of male. Scale bars = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution: Russia , China ( Beijing , Jilin , Ningxia , Shaanxi ), Korea , Japan .

Remarks: Sharp (1874) described
Philonthus rutiliventris
from Russia and Hayashi (2008) transferred it to the genus
Pseudohesperus
. Our specimens agree well with Hayashiâ€™s material (CHH).
Pseudohesperus rutiliventris ( Sharp, 1874 )
is closely related to
P. cf. eustilbus ( Kraatz, 1859 )
and
P. sparsipunctatus Li & Zhou
sp. nov.
Pseudohesperus rutiliventris
can be easily distinguished from the latter two species by head and pronotum with distinct and profound microsculpture and different aedeagus (head and pronotum without microsculpture in the latter two species). This species is reported from China for the first time.
